Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Role Of Frontiers In The Spatial Organization Of Traditional Societies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Elizabeth Arkush, Co-P.I. Patrick Mullins, will use National Science Foundation support to expand understandings of the evolution of political power in frontier zones. Frontiers are universally important in representing the spatial limits of modern and ancient states but can change considerably over time: from ambiguous and permeable to rigidly controlled and divisive. But how may political power on frontiers evolve over time and what factors may lead to different outcomes? Focusing on frontier conflict through defensive architecture, this study contributes to understandings of the long-term consequences of fortifications and border walls along political frontiers. Additionally, a landscape perspective highlights the importance of certain natural (i.e. mineral deposits, water sources, farmland) and human-made (i.e. canals, trade routes, population centers) features in determining where political power may be expressed or contested on the landscape. By shedding light on long-term causes and consequences of frontier political involvement and conflict, this project resonates well with some particular challenges faced by many modern states, like the US, in border maintenance and military action. The results and data from this project will be available in the Comparative Archaeological Database for open-access use by the broader scientific community and will be a key part of a larger regional digitization initiative called the Moche Valley Ancient Settlement Database. Finally, following a collaborative research program, this project will train Peruvian and American students in several new archaeological techniques (i.e. aerial drone mapping) while actively integrating local people with the practice of archaeological research during several workshops and public presentations of the survey results.

Through archaeological survey of the Upper Moche Valley frontier in northern Peru, this project compares the frontiers of two sequential polities, the Southern Moche State (AD 200-900) and the Chimu Empire (AD 900-1470), in order to understand how political power may evolve in frontier landscapes. Although the Chimu arguably rose from the ashes of the Moche in the lower valley, the Southern Moche State was an earlier "first-generation" polity with far more indirect methods of rule than the centralized and expansive Chimu. As their eastern frontier, the Upper Moche Valley was attractive to both polities, crucially providing canal intakes and an exchange corridor with the metal-rich highlands. Meanwhile, a plethora of prehistoric forts and defensively located or walled towns in the region point towards it being a highly contested frontier. But how did the Moche and Chimu frontiers differ in this region? And how did the involvement of these states in the frontier evolve over time? This project will address these questions by highlighting the interacting roles of (1) the qualities of a state itself, (2) the intensity and organization of frontier conflict, and (3) the use of natural and human-made landscape features. Project methodology integrates traditional full-coverage survey and controlled surface collection with cutting-edge aerial imagery and 3-D site models attained through quad-copter drone mapping. Combined into a geographic database these data will be used to reconstruct regional settlement, political boundaries, and defensive networks to understand the evolution of the Upper Moche frontier.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The foundation of this research is a systematic survey of the Upper Moche Valley conducted from January to November 2017. One objective of this study was to use samples of surface collected ceramic material to reconstruct changes in prehistoric settlement patterns. Using established ceramic chronologies, samples were separated into ware categories that can be correlated with broad time periods and also divided between highland, coastal,and chaupiyunga ceramic traditions. Ceramic analyses are still underway but statistical techniques are being used to calculate and reconstruct the intensity, nature, and extents of landscape use and occupation. Decorated fine-wares or “corporate” wares are being used as evidence for indirect political control to trace foreign political involvement with frontier communities. A substantial part of the project was using quad-copter drone photography to map sites and generate reconstructions of site architecture. These maps provide evidence, in concert with ceramic material, for foreign political power in the region. Additionally, the drone maps are key for calculations of defensibility that are being used to compare the intensity of conflict between periods.

This research project employs the indirect-direct political control heuristic grounded by a political landscape perspective to understand how (1) the indirect or direct nature of ancient polities, (2) the intensity and organization of frontier conflict, and (3) the use of the natural and anthropogenic landscape shaped the transformation of political authority in the Upper Moche Valley frontier landscape. Although some analyses are still underway, some research questions and outcomes can be explored with preliminary findings.

First, were the chaupiyunga frontiers of these polities different in predictable ways? Was the Moche frontier more indirectly controlled while the Chimú was more direct? Although I encountered several Moche adobe mounds suggesting more direct forms of control, the lack of Moche prestige goods in nearby highland-chaupiyunga colonies illustrates that interaction between Moche-coastal centers and non-coastal communities did not involve political incorporation. However, Moche-coastal settlement and canal projects clustered near these mounds, suggesting they were perhaps politically-affiliated colonies. Few direct markers of Chimú control were encountered, but highland-chaupiyunga communities were more integrated with the Chimú network of material goods. Settlement also favored heavily fortified hilltops. This coastal-highland mixing suggests a fluid Chimú frontier of allied or subject communities serving as a buffer with larger, likely belligerent, highland polities.

Second, what role did conflict with highland and/or chaupiyunga communities play in shaping this frontier? Chimú involvement in the region is paired with clear indicators of intense and large-scale conflict illustrated by a system of fortified towns and lookouts. Although most Moche settlements were defensively oriented on hilltops, conflict was likely small-scale and limited to disputes between neighboring highland-chaupiyunga communities or other colonies.Third, was Moche and Chimú political authority expressed at similar places, and if so does this reflect similar methods of engaging this landscape? People and polities were bound together in this landscape over time, as, in many instances, the Chimú built off of the legacy the Moche left behind. In particular, the areas around Moche colonies are characterized by a higher density of Chimú coastal ceramics. There is also evidence for Chimú expansion of Moche canal projects. In contrast, areas untouched by direct Moche-coastal influence exhibit mixed assemblages and indirect Chimú involvement. These data suggest that the legacy of colonization opened doors for the Chimú through coastal connections while also forcing highland-chaupiyunga peoples to renegotiate their landscape with the more invasive Chimú.

People and polities were bound together in this landscape over time, as, in many instances, the Chimú built off of the legacy the Moche left behind. In particular, the areas around Moche colonies are characterized by a higher density of Chimú coastal ceramics. There is also evidence for Chimú expansion of Moche canal projects. In contrast, areas untouched by direct Moche-coastal influence exhibit mixed assemblages and indirect Chimú involvement. These data suggest that the legacy of colonization opened doors for the Chimú through coastal connections while also forcing highland-chaupiyunga peoples to renegotiate their landscape with the more invasive Chimú.

When completed and published as a dissertation, this research project will enrich broader anthropological understandings of polities with a perspective grounded in landscapes while also advancing regional understandings of the chaupiyunga, Chimú, and Moche. In the Andes, studies that explicitly target the chaupiyunga are sparse and my research will help in clarifying the articulation of this often-forgotten frontier with the adjacent regions that are the focus of most research. Finally, living and doing aid work with chaipiyunga communities through the El Nino floods of 2017 has galvanized the researchers' commitment to the region and its people, who still, in many ways, are fighting for life on a frontier.
